tasks.context:
Create sdk/typescript/src/http-transport.ts. This module replaces raw axios calls with a composable transport that uses the existing withTimeout (from ./timeout) and retryWithBackoff (from ./retry) utilities.

Export a single class HttpTransport with constructor(config: { baseUrl: string; apiKey: string; timeout: number; maxRetries: number }) and one method: async request<T>(method: 'GET'|'POST'|'PATCH'|'DELETE', path: string, body?: unknown): Promise<T>.

Internally: (1) use buildUrl from ./request-builder to construct URL, (2) use buildHeaders from ./request-builder for auth headers, (3) wrap the native fetch() call with withTimeout() from ./timeout, (4) wrap the fetch+timeout in retryWithBackoff() from ./retry passing { maxRetries: this.config.maxRetries }, (5) use parseResponse<T>() from ./response-parser to handle the response.

Import types only — do NOT reimplement any utility logic. Max 80 lines.

Exports: HttpTransport class
Imports: withTimeout from ./timeout, retryWithBackoff from ./retry, buildUrl and buildHeaders from ./request-builder, parseResponse from ./response-parser

issues.description: Unnecessary try-catch wrapper in fetchWithRetry - the catch block just re-throws without adding value
Could benefit from JSDoc comments on the public class and method for better developer experience
The try/catch inside fetchWithRetry simply rethrows the caught error, which is redundant and could be removed for brevity.

strengths: Correctly imports and composes all required utilities without reimplementing logic
Proper TypeScript generics usage for type-safe responses
Clean separation of concerns - URL building, headers, timeout, retry, and parsing all delegated
Handles request body logic correctly (only for POST/PATCH, with proper Content-Type)
Stays well under the 80-line limit at ~35 lines
No hardcoded values or security issues
Follows the exact interface specified in the task
Imports only required utilities without reimplementing logic
Proper use of generics and no use of `any`
Correct composition of timeout and retry wrappers
Adheres to max line count and naming conventions

tasks.context:
Create sdk/typescript/src/enhanced-client.ts. This is a new client class that composes HttpTransport (from ./http-transport) with resolveConfig (from ./client-config) and RateLimitTracker (from ./rate-limit).

Export class CountableClient with constructor(config: InvoicaClientConfig) that: (1) calls resolveConfig(config) to get resolved config, (2) creates new HttpTransport(resolved), (3) creates new RateLimitTracker().

Then provide these methods, each calling this.transport.request():
- getInvoice(id: string): Promise<Invoice>
- createInvoice(input: InvoiceCreateInput): Promise<Invoice>
- listInvoices(params?: {limit?: number; offset?: number; status?: string}): Promise<InvoiceListResponse>
- getSettlement(id: string): Promise<Settlement>
- listSettlements(params?: {limit?: number; offset?: number}): Promise<SettlementListResponse>

Import types from ./types. Import HttpTransport from ./http-transport. Import resolveConfig, InvoicaClientConfig from ./client-config. Import RateLimitTracker from ./rate-limit.

Import Invoice, InvoiceCreateInput, InvoiceListResponse, Settlement, SettlementListResponse from ./types.

This class IS the CountableClient that index.ts already exports. Max 90 lines.

issues.description: RateLimitTracker is created but never configured - may need initialization parameters or default limits
No input validation on method parameters (e.g., empty string IDs, negative limits/offsets)

strengths: Correctly implements all required methods as specified
Proper composition of HttpTransport, resolveConfig, and RateLimitTracker
Clean TypeScript generics usage with proper return types
Consistent rate limiting applied to all API methods
Good JSDoc documentation on the class
Follows single responsibility principle - pure composition layer
Stays well under the 90-line limit (29 lines)
Proper async/await usage throughout

Create sdk/typescript/src/enhanced-client-extras.ts. This module adds API key and webhook management methods as standalone function factories.

Export two functions:

1. createApiKeyMethods(transport: HttpTransport) — returns an object with:
   - createApiKey(name: string): Promise<ApiKeyCreateResponse> — POST /api-keys {name}
   - revokeApiKey(id: string): Promise<void> — DELETE /api-keys/{id}
   - listApiKeys(): Promise<ApiKey[]> — GET /api-keys

2. createWebhookMethods(transport: HttpTransport) — returns an object with:
   - registerWebhook(config: WebhookRegistrationConfig): Promise<WebhookRegistration> — POST /webhooks
   - listWebhooks(): Promise<WebhookListResponse> — GET /webhooks
   - deleteWebhook(id: string): Promise<void> — DELETE /webhooks/{id}

Each factory returns an object of methods that call transport.request(). Max 70 lines.

tasks.context:
Create sdk/typescript/src/debug.ts. A debug logger utility for the Invoica SDK.

Export:
1. interface DebugLogger { log(message: string, data?: unknown): void; warn(message: string, data?: unknown): void; error(message: string, data?: unknown): void; }

2. function createDebugLogger(namespace: string): DebugLogger
   - If process.env.INVOICA_DEBUG is truthy, log to console with '[invoica:namespace]' prefix and ISO timestamp
   - If INVOICA_DEBUG is falsy, all methods are no-ops (empty functions that do nothing)
   - log() uses console.log, warn() uses console.warn, error() uses console.error

3. function isDebugEnabled(): boolean — returns true when process.env.INVOICA_DEBUG is set and truthy

Max 50 lines. No external dependencies.

issues.description: Using nullish coalescing (??) with empty string for data parameter - could be cleaner to handle undefined data separately or use conditional logging

strengths: Exact interface match to specification
Proper TypeScript typing with no 'any' usage
Clean separation of concerns with helper function
Efficient no-op implementation when debug disabled
Correct console method mapping (log/warn/error)

tasks.context:
Create backend/src/middleware/idempotency.ts. An Express middleware for idempotent POST requests.

Export:
1. function idempotencyMiddleware(): RequestHandler
   - Reads 'Idempotency-Key' header from req.headers (lowercase: 'idempotency-key')
   - If header not present, call next() and skip
   - If present, check an in-memory Map<string, { statusCode: number; body: unknown; createdAt: number }>
   - Cache hit: return res.status(cached.statusCode).json(cached.body) immediately
   - Cache miss: wrap res.json() to capture the response, store in cache with the idempotency key, then send response
   - On each request, clean expired entries (older than 86400000 ms = 24 hours)

2. function getIdempotencyKey(req: Request): string | undefined — returns req.headers['idempotency-key'] as string

Import { Request, Response, NextFunction, RequestHandler } from 'express'. Max 65 lines.

issues.description: Missing unit tests - idempotency logic is critical and should have comprehensive test coverage
Cache cleanup runs on every request - could be optimized with periodic cleanup for high-traffic scenarios
The middleware does not check HTTP method; it will cache responses for any method. Consider restricting it to POST requests as implied by the spec.

strengths: Correctly handles header as both string and array (Express header edge case)
Proper TypeScript types with no 'any' usage
Clean separation of concerns with getIdempotencyKey utility function
Efficient cache expiration cleanup on each request
Proper response wrapping that preserves original Express behavior
Good JSDoc documentation
Meets exact line count requirement (58 lines vs 65 max)
Follows Express middleware patterns correctly
Proper extraction of single or array form of the Idempotency-Key header
In-memory cache with TTL and cleanup logic runs on each request
TypeScript-strict–compliant, no use of `any`
JSDoc comments present and clear
No hardcoded secrets or security issues

tasks.context:
Create backend/src/middleware/api-version.ts. An Express middleware for API version negotiation.

Export:
1. interface ApiVersionRequest extends Request { apiVersion: string }

2. function apiVersionMiddleware(supportedVersions: string[]): RequestHandler
   - Reads 'X-API-Version' header, defaults to last element of supportedVersions array (latest)
   - If requested version NOT in supportedVersions, return res.status(400).json({ error: { code: 'UNSUPPORTED_VERSION', message: `API version ${requested} is not supported. Supported versions: ${supportedVersions.join(', ')}` } })
   - Sets (req as ApiVersionRequest).apiVersion = requestedVersion
   - Sets res.setHeader('X-API-Version', requestedVersion)
   - Calls next()

3. function getApiVersion(req: Request): string — returns (req as ApiVersionRequest).apiVersion || 'v1'

Import { Request, Response, NextFunction, RequestHandler } from 'express'. Max 55 lines.

issues.description: Missing JSDoc comments on public functions for better documentation

strengths: Exact implementation matches task specification
Proper TypeScript interface extension of Express Request
Correct error response format with structured error object
Appropriate use of type assertions and header handling
Clean, readable code under the 55-line limit (24 lines)
Proper Express middleware pattern with RequestHandler return type
Good default fallback logic for API version
No hardcoded values or security issues
Strictly follows the spec: reads X-API-Version header, validates against supported versions, and returns the correct 400 error payload.
Defines ApiVersionRequest interface and properly casts Request to include apiVersion.
Sets the X-API-Version response header and invokes next() in success path.
getApiVersion utility matches the spec and provides a sensible default.
No use of any or insecure patterns.

tasks.context:
Create frontend/app/docs/webhooks/verification/page.tsx. A Next.js App Router page documenting webhook signature verification.

Export default function WebhookVerificationPage() that returns JSX with:
1. h1 'Webhook Verification'
2. Intro: 'Invoica signs webhook payloads using HMAC-SHA256. Verify signatures to ensure webhook authenticity.'
3. Section 'How It Works' with an ordered list (<ol>):
   - 'Invoica sends the payload with an x-invoica-signature header'
   - 'Your server computes HMAC-SHA256 of the raw body using your webhook secret'
   - 'Compare computed signature with the header using timing-safe comparison'
4. Code example in <pre><code> showing Express route:
   - app.post('/webhooks', express.raw({type: 'application/json'}), (req, res) => {...})
   - Get signature from req.headers['x-invoica-signature']
   - Call verifySignature(req.body.toString(), WEBHOOK_SECRET, signature)
   - Return 200 if valid, 401 if invalid
5. Section 'Security Best Practices' as <ul> with 4 items:
   - Always use timing-safe comparison (built into verifySignature)
   - Store webhook secrets in environment variables
   - Use HTTPS endpoints only
   - Log failed verification attempts for monitoring

'use client' directive. Tailwind: max-w-4xl mx-auto py-12 px-6, bg-gray-900 text-gray-100 p-4 rounded-lg. Max 110 lines.
